Svayambhu

Digital Critical Edition and Translation of an Old Javanese Juridical Text

Edited by Arlo Griffiths & Timothy Lubin

  • Witnesses
  • Metadata

List of Witnesses

  • L: Leiden, Universiteitsbibliotheek, the Netherlands, Or. 4530: Balinese script on paper, van der Tuuk collection
  • K: Kirtya, Singaraja, Bali, Indonesia, 774 (kropak 3) II A/3/774: Balinese script on lontar
  • M: Kirtya, Singaraja, Bali, Indonesia, 280 (kropak 3): Balinese script on lontar; transcripts HKS 3046; also LOr?
  • SvaMSS: The Sanskrit text as implied by the Svayambhu manuscripts
  • EdO: Olivelle, Patrick. 2005. Manu’s Code of Law: A Critical Edition and Translation of the Mānava-Dharmásāstra. New York: Oxford University Press.

Metadata of the Edition

  • Title: Svayambhu. Digital Critical Edition and Translation of an Old Javanese Juridical Text
  • Text Identifier: DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

invocation

L1K1vM1vavighnam astu.

1.

Account of Dharma

1.

anuṣṭubh

vyavahārān didr̥kṣus tu brāhmaṇaiḥ saha pārthivaḥ | mantrajñair mantribhiś caiva vinītaḥ praviśet sabhām ||
  • MDhŚ08.001

1.1

kunaṅ ulaha saṅ prabhu, uniṅānira taṅ vyavahāranikaṅ rāt, arovaṅa ta sira brāhmaṇa vihikan(1) maṅaji, lavan mantri vruh(2) maviveka(3), sulakṣaṇaha ta sira tumamaha riṅ sabhā.

2.

anuṣṭubh

tatrāsīnaḥ sthito vāpi pāṇim udyamya dakṣiṇam | vinītaveṣābharaṇaḥ paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām ||
  • MDhŚ08.002

2.1

aliṅgihāpagəha(4) ta sira riṅ sabhā, taṅanira tṅən atah ulahaknira, hayvātuduh-tuduh*(5) kiva(6), bhūṣaṇa-pahyasniṅ vvaṅ suśīlātah(7) lviranira, iṅət-iṅətənirātah yogyāyogyani(8) kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

3.

anuṣṭubh

pratyahaṁ deśadr̥ṣṭaiś ca śāstradr̥ṣṭaiś ca hetubhiḥ | aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu nibaddhāni pr̥thak pr̥thak ||
  • MDhŚ08.003

3.1

*sari masiha(9) sirān ṅiṅət-iṅəta makasādhanaṅ(10) varah-varah(11) saṅ hyaṅ āgama mānavādi(12), mvaṅ sakinapagəhaknikaṅ sapañjiṅ(13) deśanya, deśa ṅaranya,(14) sakaḍaṅayan(15), sajasun(16) vuṅkal, savuravan(17), sakanuruhan, an(18) hana *kaparəkanya deniṅ āgama, ya ika(19) deśadr̥ṣṭa ṅaranya, an tan(20) deśa sasiki svadeśanikaṅ mavyavahāra(21), aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu(22), irikā sthānaniṅ vyavahāra vvalu(23) vlas kvehnya, salviraniṅ vicāraniṅ(24) vyavahāra, hana tinmunya ṅkāna salah siki, paḍa madudva-dudvan(25) viṣayanya.

4.

anuṣṭubh

hiṁsāṁ yaḥ kurute kaś cid deyaṁ vā na prayacchati | sthāne te dve vivādasya bhinno ’ṣṭādaśadhā punaḥ ||
  • This stanza is absent from Olivelle 2005’s constituted text, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for one manuscript. The stanza occurs in ed. Mandlik 1886 8.4 with reading bhinno, where the Svayambhu implies bhinne.

4.1

hiṁsāṁ yaḥ(26) kurute kaś cit, hana vvaṅ mamatyani nirdoṣa, kunaṅ(27) deyam vā(28) na prayacchati(29), tan paveh irikaṅ yogya vehakna(30), aveh irikaṅ tan yogya vehaknanya kunaṅ, sthāne(31) te dve vivādasya(32), ya ika(33) sthānaniṅ vyavahāra, rvaṅ siki mūlanya(34), bhinne(35) ’ṣṭādaśadhā(36) punaḥ, matmahan ta ya vvalu vlas vkasan.

5.

anuṣṭubh

teṣām ādyam r̥ṇādānaṁ nikṣepo ’svāmivikrayaḥ | saṁbhūya ca samutthānaṁ dattasyānapakarma ca ||
  • MDhŚ08.004

anuṣṭubh

vetanasyaiva cādānaṁ(37) saṁvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ | krayavikrayānuśayo vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.005

anuṣṭubh

sīmāvivādadharmaś ca pāruṣye daṇḍavācike | steyaṁ ca sāhasaṁ caiva strīsaṁgrahaṇam eva ca ||
  • MDhŚ08.006

anuṣṭubh

strīpuṁdharmo vibhāgaś ca dyūtam āhvaya(38) eva ca | padāny aṣṭādaśaitāni vyavahārasthitāv iha(39) ||
  • MDhŚ08.007

5.1

lvirnya, teṣām ādyam(40) r̥ṇādānam(41), tan kasahuraniṅ hutaṅ(42), ādiniṅ vyavahāra. nikṣepa, tan kavehaniṅ patuvava(43). asvāmi(44)vikraya(45), hadval tan dravya. sambhūya ca(46) samutthānam(47), tan kaduman ulihiṅ kinabehan. dattasyānapakarma(48) ca, *karuddhāniṅ(49) huvus vinehakən.

5.2

vetanasya(51) na ca dānam(52) (50) , tan kavehaniṅ(53) upahan. samvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ, advā riṅ samaya. krayavikrayānuśayo(54), alarāmbəknyān pamlinya kunaṅ. vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ(55), vivādaniṅ(56) *pinaṅvanakən mvaṅ maṅvan.

5.3

sīmāvivādadharmaś ca, kahucapaniṅ vatəs. pāruṣye daṇḍavācike, ḍaṇḍaniṅ sāhasa(57), vākpāruṣya. steyam(58), pavr̥ttiniṅ maliṅ. sāhasam, ulah sāhasa. strīsaṁgrahaṇam eva ca(59), ulah tan yogya riṅ strī, strīpuṁdharmo, dharmaniṅ laki-strī.

5.4

vibhāgaś(60) ca, kadumaniṅ dravya. dyūtam(61), totohan tan(62) prāṇi. āhvānam(63), totohan prāṇi. padāny(64) aṣṭādaśaitāni, nahan ta vvalu(65) vlas lvirnya. vyavahārasthitānīha(66), byakta pinakasthānaniṅ(67) vyavahāra.

6.

anuṣṭubh

eṣu sthāneṣu bhūyiṣṭhaṁ vivādaṁ caratāṁ nr̥ṇām | dharmaṁ śāśvatam āśritya kuryāt kāryavinirṇayam ||
  • MDhŚ08.008

6.1

eṣu(68) sthāneṣu(69) bhūyiṣṭham(70), ikaṅ vyavahāra(71)sthāna vvalu(72) vlas, kapva hana katmunya(73) ṅkana(74), kapagəhakna(75) saṅ prabhu, yuktinikaṅ vyavahāranya, apan gavayaknanira pagəh i(76) kāryanikaṅ(77) yogya pagəhaknanira.

7.

anuṣṭubh

yadā svayaṁ na kuryāt tu nr̥patiḥ kāryadarśanam | tadā niyuñjyād vidvāṁsaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ kāryadarśane ||
  • MDhŚ08.009

7.1

kunaṅ saṅ prabhu hayva sira gumavayakən(78) ikaṅ kāryāmivakṣa*(79) guṇadoṣa, akona ta sira ri(80) saṅ brāhmaṇa(81) vihikan maṅaji(82), kumavruhana yogyāyogya(83)nikaṅ vvaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

8.

anuṣṭubh

aṣṭādaśapadābhijñaṁ prāḍvivāketi saṁjñitam | ānvīkṣikyāṁ ca kuśalaṁ śrutismr̥tiparāyaṇam ||
  • This stanza is absent from the constituted text in Olivelle 2005, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for ms. Ox2 after 8.9. Mandlik (p. 877) and Jha include the stanza at the beginning of Medhātithi’s comment on 8.9; in his notes, Jha (v. 9, p. 490) cites citations of this verse in medieval scholastic works. In contrast with the cases in Div. XX and YY, van Naerssen (van Naerssen 1956) did not notice that the Old Javanese text here implies the presence of this stanza because the Sanskrit original is not quoted.

8.1

saṅ brāhmaṇa saṅ vruh riṅ aṣṭādaśavyavahāra,(84) sira ta(85) saṅ sinaṅguh prāgvivāka(86), saṅ vruh riṅ aji tarka, vruh(87) riṅ śruti(88) veda.

9.

anuṣṭubh

vivāde pr̥cchati praśnaṁ pratipraśnaṁ tathaiva ca | priyapūrvaṁ prāg vadati prāḍvivākas tataḥ smr̥taḥ ||
  • Brh_1,1.69 This stanza is present neither in the constituted text of Olivelle 2005, nor in its app. crit., but is known to have occurred in the Br̥haspatismr̥ti, a text often cited by medieval Indian dharmaśāstra authors. The Old Javanese paraphrase suggests that its author knew the Sanskrit stanza with a reading vicāre for vivāde.

9.1

kunaṅ ikaṅ takvan iṅ(89) vicāra, gavayakna rumuhun, sādhana saṅ prāgvivāka irikaṅ(90) mavyavahāra kalih, vivekanira ta sahurnya vkasan, mataṅyan(91) prāgvivāka(92) pva ṅaranira.

10.

anuṣṭubh

so ’sya kāryāṇi saṁpaśyet sabhyair eva tribhir vr̥taḥ | sabhām eva praviśyāgryām āsīnaḥ sthita eva vā ||
  • MDhŚ08.010

10.1

haṅiṅət-iṅəta ta(93) saṅ prāgvivāka, hi kāryanikaṅ(94) mavyavahāra kalih, harovaṅa ta sira vvaṅ yogya riṅ sabhā(95) tigaṅ viji, tumamaha(96) ta sirāluṅguhāpagəha(97) riṅ sabhā.

11.

anuṣṭubh

yasmin deśe niṣīdanti viprā vedavidas trayaḥ | rājñaś ca prakr̥to vidvān brahmaṇas tāṁ sabhāṁ viduḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.011

11.1

saṅ brāhmaṇa tigaṅ siki, paḍa vruh maṅaji, hana brāhmaṇa sasiki prajñān vidagdha, vinidhi muṅgva riṅ deśa saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ deśa papupulanira, yeka deśa sabhā ṅaranya de saṅ paṇḍita(98).

12.

upajāti

na sā sabhā yatra na santi vr̥ddhā vr̥ddhā na te ye na vadanti dharmam | nāsau dharmo yatra na satyam asti na tat satyaṁ yac chalenānuviddham ||
  • NarSm mā. 3.17/NMS vya. 80
  • MDhŚ08.012 dharmo viddhas tv adharmeṇa sabhāṁ yatropatiṣṭhate | śalyaṁ cāsya na kr̥ntanti viddhās tatra sabhāsadaḥ ||

12.1

ikaṅ sabhā(99), yan tan ana saṅ vr̥ddhah tan sabhā ṅaranya, saṅ vr̥ddhah yan tan vruh iṅ(100) dharma, tan vr̥ddhaḥ ṅaranira, saṅ vruh iṅ(101) dharma yan tan agəgvana(102) kajātyan, tan dharma ṅaranikā, kunaṅ yan tan ginavayakən(103) ikaṅ dharma riṅ sabhā, sukət paṅəməh ṅaranikā sahaneṅ(104) sabhā, mapan(105) ikaṅ deśa kinahananiṅ dharma, tan kavoraniṅ(106) adharmi, yeka sabhā ṅaranya.

13.

anuṣṭubh

sabhā vā na praveṣṭavyā vaktavyaṁ vā samañjasam | abruvan vibruvan vāpi naro bhavati kilbiṣī ||
  • MDhŚ08.013

13.1

kunaṅ hikaṅ vvaṅ haṅujarakən prāya yukti, salah denya vkasan, makveh ujarnya, vvaṅ katon doṣanya(107), ika ta kabeh tan yogya tumamaha riṅ sabhā.

14.

anuṣṭubh

yatra dharmo hy adharmeṇa satyaṁ yatrānr̥tena ca | hanyate prekṣamāṇānāṁ hatās tatra sabhāsadaḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.014

14.1

mataṅyan maṅkana, dharmanika saṅ uniṅa riṅ dharma, hilaṅ ikā deniṅ adharma riṅ sabhā, kasatyanira(108) maṅkanātah hilaṅnikā deniṅ adva riṅ sabhā, yapvan alah juga dharma deniṅ adharma, halah juga satya deniṅ adva, paḍa hana pva ya riṅ sabhā, patimbunaniṅ(109) kunapa ṅaraniṅ sabhā yan maṅkana.

15.

anuṣṭubh

dharma eva hato hanti dharmo rakṣati rakṣitaḥ | tasmād dharmo na hantavyo mā no dharmo hato ’vadhīt ||
  • MDhŚ08.015

15.1

kunaṅ yan iṅilaṅakən saṅ hyaṅ dharma, maləs juga sira maṅilaṅakən, yan rinakṣa saṅ hyaṅ dharma maləs juga sira maṅrakṣa(110), mataṅyan(111) maṅkana, hayvāṅilaṅakən dharma, liṅniṅ vvaṅ, tan paṅilaṅakən pva kita(112) dharma, tan paṅilaṅakən sira hiri ya, maṅkana(113) liṅ atəhər pramāṇastava(114).

16.

  • unknown

16.1

hapan(115) tan ana ləviha sakeṅ dharma, sira pinakapramāṇan riṅ(116) loka, sira ta pinakasvarga saṅ magave(118) hayu, sira pinakakaləpasan saṅ paṇḍita, tan maṅkana hikaṅ vvaṅ adharma, tan ana gumantyana(119) maṅkanāta saṅka pisana tuvi.(117)

17.

  • unknown

17.1

mapan ikaṅ loka kabeh, dharma humagəhakən ika, kinapagəhakən pva sira de saṅ yatna, maləsira magəhakən, apan tan pāpa hikaṅ loka(120) maṅkana, ikaṅ tan aṅilaṅakən dharma.

18.

anuṣṭubh

vr̥ṣo hi bhagavān dharmas tasya yaḥ kurute tv alam | vr̥ṣalaṁ taṁ vidur devās tasmād dharmaṁ na lopayet ||
  • MDhŚ08.016

18.1

mataṅnyan(121) maṅkana, ləmbu rūpa bhaṭāra(122) dharma, hana ta vvaṅ(123) tan agave dharma, yeka pāpa liṅniṅ deva, maṅkana pva ya, hayva kita maṅilaṅakən dharma.

19.

anuṣṭubh

eka eva suhr̥d dharmo nidhāne ’py anuyāti yaḥ | śarīreṇa samaṁ nāśaṁ sarvam anyad dhi gacchati ||
  • MDhŚ08.017

19.1

saṅ(124) tumut ri kālaniṅ pati sira ta bhaṭāra dharma, mitra tan pakarva pva, parəṅ ilaṅ mvaṅ śarīra, mvaṅ dharma, kunaṅ hikaṅ dr̥vya len sakerika, salah paran ika.

20.

anuṣṭubh

pādo ’dharmasya kartāraṁ pādaḥ sākṣiṇam r̥cchati | pādaḥ sabhāsadaḥ sarvān pādo rājānam r̥cchati ||
  • MDhŚ08.018

20.1

saṅ hyaṅ dharma saparəpatan(125) tinəmuniṅ mavyavahāra yan satya, maṅkana hikaṅ sākṣi yan satya, hanmu saparəpatanira(126) saṅ hyaṅ(127) dharma, maṅkana saṅ mavivakṣa kabeh, yan satya hanəmu saparəpatanira(128) saṅ hyaṅ dharmātah, saṅ prabhu hanəmu saparəpatanirātah(129), hagəṅ juga phalaniṅ kasatyan(130) ginavayakən.

21.

anuṣṭubh

rājā bhavaty anenās tu mucyante ca sabhāsadaḥ | eno gacchati kartāraṁ nindārho yatra nindyate ||
  • MDhŚ08.019

21.1

saṅ prabhu tan kahanan sira riṅ(131) pāpa, saṅ mavivakṣa kabeh luput sira riṅ pāpa, ikaṅ mavyavahāra salah pakṣanya juga təmpuhanya, nininda siṅ(132) saṅkananya, (133) deśa kahananya.

anuṣṭubh

jātimātropajīvī vā kāmaṁ syād brāhmaṇabruvaḥ | dharmapravaktā nr̥pater na tu śūdraḥ kathaṁ cana ||
  • MDhŚ08.020

22.

anuṣṭubh

yasya śūdras tu kurute rājño dharmavivecanam | tasya sīdati tad rāṣṭraṁ paṅke gaur iva paśyataḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.021

22.1

maṅkana saṅ prabhu, yan śūdra prāgvivākanira, kaḍatvanira durbala(134) kṣaya, kadi ləmbu kaptək riṅ(135) latək ajro.

  • Bhīṣmaparva 124.19: kadi ləmbu kapətək iṅ latək

23.

anuṣṭubh

yad rāṣṭraṁ śūdrabhūyiṣṭhaṁ nāstikākrāntam advijam | vinaśyaty āśu tat kr̥tsnaṁ durbhikṣavyādhipīḍitam ||
  • MDhŚ08.022

23.1

ikaṅ rājya, yan kakehaniṅ(136) śūdra, hakveh vvaṅ(137) manayākən deva hiriya, tan pabrāhmaṇa, ikaṅ rājya maṅkana, śīghra hilaṅ deniṅ lapā vyādhi bhaya kaḍatvanira.

24.

  • unknown vyavahārān svayaṁ paśyet sabhyaiḥ parivr̥to ’nvaham || YDh 1.360 = BṛhSm 1.1.106]

24.1

maṅkana pva ya, maṅutusa ta sirāmivakṣaha*, vvaṅ vruh iṅ āgama, śīghra maṅucapa yan tinakvanan, saṅ makveh kavruhnira(138) śruti veda, paḍaməlakna vataṅan pāt, ikaṅ vet an pamivakṣana*, sakveh saṅ humuṅguh(139) irika, sira ta(140) paḍa umiṅət-iṅəta sarasaniṅ vyavahāra.

25.

anuṣṭubh

dharmāsanam adhiṣṭhāya saṁvītāṅgaḥ samāhitaḥ | praṇamya lokapālebhyaḥ kāryadarśanam ārabhet ||
  • MDhŚ08.023

25.1

maṅkanānakna(141) sajiniṅ vataṅan, apuy riṅ payajñan(142), kumbha mesya bañu, halalaṅ, sarvavīja,(143) maṇik curiga muṅgva riṅ səṇḍi. tumama pva saṅ prāgvivāka riṅ sabhā, mavḍihana, asalimputa(144), maṅañjaliha riṅ caturlokapāla, lumkasa ta sira maṅiṅət-iṅəta kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

26.

anuṣṭubh

arthānarthāv ubhau buddhvā dharmādharmau ca kevalau | varṇakrameṇa sarvāṇi paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām ||
  • MDhŚ08.025

26.1

kavruhananira kaṅ ujar adon lavan tan padon, mvaṅ ikaṅ(145) tuhu lavan adva, nahan ta kāryanikaṅ vyavahāra kalih, iniṅət-iṅətənira, tumutana kramaniṅ varṇanikaṅ vyavahāra.

27.

anuṣṭubh

bāhyair vibhāvayel liṅgair bhāvam antargataṁ nr̥ṇām | svaravarṇeṅgitākāraiś cakṣuṣā ceṣṭitena ca ||
  • MDhŚ08.025

27.1

adharma(146)buddhinikaṅ vyavahāra, iṅətakənanya(147) tuvi, kavruhana de saṅ prāgvivāka, vāhyaliṅgaiḥ(148), makanimitta(149) *paṅanumāna(150) katon, śabdanya kasalahan, kavnəsan, heṅas(151) tan asiga ri(152) vkasan, mulat(153) muliṅā, sahulah(154) alaṅə̄(155).

28.

anuṣṭubh

ākārair iṅgitair gatyā ceṣṭayā bhāṣitena ca | netravaktravikāraiś ca gr̥hyate ’ntargataṁ manaḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.026

28.1

takvanikaṅ manah, halit pinakabuṅkahiṅ buddhi, yadyapi(156) hinə-həttakənya(157) hinət-ətakənya(158) denikaṅ avyavahāra, yan adharma, kavruhana hikā de saṅ prāgvivāka, makanimitta(159) vāhyaliṅga(160). ākāraiḥ(161), iṅgitaiḥ(162), lakunya, ulahnya, śabdanya, vikāraniṅ hulatnya, vnəsniṅ mukanya.

colophon

iti dharmacarita(163).

2.

Protection of Faithful Women

29.

anuṣṭubh

bāladāyādikaṁ rikthaṁ tāvad rājānupālayet | yāvat sa syāt samāvr̥tto yāvad vātītaśaiśavaḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.027 Our mss. suggest a variant reading yāvat na syāt, i.e., yāvan na syāt, in pāda c.

29.1

kunaṅ dr̥vya kaliliraniṅ(164) rare *tuvu-tuvuh(165), kəmitən kəkəsana saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ dr̥vya, yan apa maṅkana, yāvan na(166) syāt samāvr̥tto(167), yan tan uvus(168) maṅaji, ya(169) tapvan vnaṅ rumakṣa dr̥vyanya, kunaṅ yan uvus mulih sakiṅ gurunya, vnaṅ rumakṣa dr̥vyanya, vehakna ikaṅ dr̥vya iriya.

30.

anuṣṭubh

vaśāputrāsu caivaṁ syād rakṣaṇaṁ niṣkulāsu ca | pativratāsu ca strīṣu vidhavāsv āturāsu ca ||
  • MDhŚ08.028

30.1

strī valva-valvan mānak raray rakṣanən(170) ikā de saṅ prabhu, strī valu(171) tan pabapebu(172), strī valu vyādhi, *makapaṅguhan(173) satyanya riṅ jalunya, ika ta katiga rakṣanən de saṅ prabhu, sira haṅilaṅakna yan ana vvaṅ avamāna(174) hiriya, mataṅhyan maṅkana, ika kasatyan haneriya, pāvak bhaṭāra dharma katvaṅananira(175), kunaṅ yan satya ikaṅ strī, hayva(176) saṅ prabhu parabyāpāra irikā kabeh.

anuṣṭubh

  • MDhŚ08.029

anuṣṭubh

  • MDhŚ08.058
  • The paraphrase suggests that the received reading, instead of vadhyo, was bādhyo, baddhyo or bandhyo, the former two being among the variant readings recorded by Olivelle. The paraphrase also seems to presuppose a reading trisākṣiṇam bruyāt (or the like) instead of tripakṣāt prabruyāt. But no such variant is reported in Olivelle’s edition.

anuṣṭubh

132.

anuṣṭubh

ādhiḥ sīmā bāladhanaṁ nikṣepopanidhiḥ striyaḥ | rājasvaṁ śrotriyasvaṁ ca na bhogena praṇaśyati ||
yaḥ svāminānanujñātam ādhiṁ bhūṅkte ’vicakṣaṇaḥ | tenārdhavr̥ddhir moktavyā tasya bhogasya niṣkr̥tiḥ ||
  • MDhŚ08.149-08.150 Our author seems to have known the first Sanskrit stanza with the reading ādhisīmā. It is unclear whether he knew the second at all — whether the phrases after tan ilaṅa ya still concern the first stanza, whether they are a loose rendering of stanza 150 as we know it, or whether they correspond to a radically different version of that stanza. The use of a lowest-level instead of final punctuation after tan ilaṅa ya in all three manuscripts suggests that the scribes regarded what follows as part of the preceding paraphrase.

132.1

Here begins a passage where the respective readings of our two witnesses are hard to reconcile with each other and with the underlying Sanskrit text as we know it. Our editorial choices are quite speculative.
ya vacananta, … brahmā. only in K
There is nothing at all in L corresponding to the Sanskrit stanza, while K seems to give here a paraphrase that only corresponds to the second half of the stanza. It can hardly be a coincidence that we find, a few paragraphs down (), and then in both manuscripts, a paraphrase of the first hemistich of the Sanskrit stanza.kīrti em.

tan· pva Ltan vruḥ pa Ktakvanən conj.
takvan LK
We cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanən is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanən ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 28.ikaṅ ulahK

Manuscript L inserts a substantial interpolation between two iterations of the lemma. The interpolation notably contains the full text of MDhŚ 8.139 and an unidentified Sanskrit stanza. Although having stanza 8.139, with paraphrase, in this general part of the text is potentially attractive, the fact that the stanza is quoted in full is suspect, and the precise locus where it is inserted interrupts the paraphrase of 8.137. On these grounds, we favor the hypothesis that the segment of text found only in this witness is extraneous to our text.pirak paṇa sapuluhLK

In order for the arithmetic in this paragraph to work, we absolutely need this sentence to state a quantity of twelve and a half māṣas (i.e., 12 māṣa + 2 kupaṅ). Should we also supply ma before mā? Probably not, as ku in the last sentence is also not preceded by ma. For our author, ma, su seems to have been a fixed combination with ma no longer able freely to be combined with other units, as happens in the epigraphic corpus.2LK

ma:, 1, 9 K6, riṅ sapuluh tahun conj.
A riṁ salek· LKA, riṁ salek· M
The witnesses clearly point to a value of 9 suvarṇas. This means the total number of māṣas in question is at least 144, i.e., a factor of 10 times the annual yield on the loan. For this reason, we conjecture that the number corruptly transmitted as A in all witnesses was a 6, reject the reading riṅ salek despite unanimous manuscript support for it, and conjecture sapuluh tahun. It is not evident why our author would have thought of a ten-year period in the present context, but it may be relevant that this duration will be mentioned explicitly two time not far below (div 130, 132).

Our author seems to have known the first Sanskrit stanza with the reading ādhisīmā. It is unclear whether he knew the second at all — whether the phrases after tan ilaṅa ya still concern the first stanza, whether they are a loose rendering of stanza 150 as we know it, or whether they correspond to a radically different version of that stanza. The use of a lowest-level instead of final punctuation after tan ilaṅa ya in all three manuscripts suggests that the scribes regarded what follows as part of the preceding paraphrase.dravyaniṅLK

aṅalaṅ-alaṅi Mśeṣaniṅ tukon … anak putuniṅ ahutaṅ thus formulated in L
śeṣaniṁ ḍaṇḍa, śeṣa vlan·, Ika ta kabeḥ, yan matikaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya Ksesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya Msesaniṁ, sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya Mśeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya KM
Paradosis of KM: śeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya
The two alternative ways of reading the last sentence, represented respectively by L and K #M, seem equally acceptable. It is remarkable that where L reads śeṣaniṅ tukon, K #M seem to reflect śeṣa vlyan in their hyparchetype, while they agree with L on reading śeṣaniṅ ḍaṇḍa. There is external textual evidence in Perpusnas L882 (mvah hutaṅ tan kaliliranā deniṅ putra, hutaṅ tan paputra, hutaṅ totohan, śeṣadaṇḍa, hutaṅ tukon, hutaṅ sajə̄ṅ) that might support conjecturing śeṣa ḍaṇḍa in our text. There is also evidence that tukon and vəlyan were felt to be equivalent in this genre of literature UBL Or 5037 (ana vvaṅ istrī linamar saptapayu sinrahan ikaṅ tukon mati taṅ istrīkaṅ sinrahan tukon vəlyan ika si baṅavan ika tan vaṅsulakna ikaṅ tukon).

kunaṅ […] sākṣinya
The readings of both witnesses cannot be reconciled with each other without doing violence to the one or the other. It is noticeable that the reading of K is much more coherent than that of L. By the principle of lectio difficilior potior, L’s’ readings should probably be preferred: they are less consistent, somewhat elliptical, and compressed, whereas K’s readings look like an expansion and systematization. QUOTE K VERBATIM?kunaṅ […] kunaṅ sakaton sakarəṅə̄ dentasakaR̥ṅəntenta sākṣi, yen tuhu, śīghra
For the paraphrase of the second hemistisch of the Sanskrit stanza, see .kunaṅ […] 2.
The second half of the Sanskrit stanza it not glossed at all. It is likely that corresponding sentences of the Old Javanese text have been lost due to eye-skip.ikaṅ […] yān
All witnesses read a lowest-level punctuation sign here and after the gloss of the next stanza: it seems that MDhŚ08.154–156 were considered to form a group.ikaikaṁ […] nikaṅ inakuniṅ bapanya panahuranya
This paragraph is transmitted ibn exceedingly corrupt form in all witnesses; we are forced to take recourse to extreme conjectures to obtain a coherent text.

^363 . kunaṅ […] sākṣinya] The readings of both witnesses cannot be reconciled with each other without doing violence to the one or the other. It is noticeable that the reading of K is much more coherent than that of L. By the principle of lectio difficilior potior, L’s’ readings should probably be preferred: they are less consistent, somewhat elliptical, and compressed, whereas K’s readings look like an expansion and systematization. ^439 . takvanən] conj., takvanLK • We cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanən is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanən ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 28.

ka, riṅ mavutaṁ yan masaṅketa:, yapva ta mityeṁ vuhus riṁ purvvaka:, ḍaṇḍanika: de bhūpatya, pañca satapa1×ṇa, kunaṁṅ apuvara haṅasiḥ dvigunotama ḍaṇḍa || ○ ||

anuṣṭubh

nipṭiṁ vak nityaṁ* krodaṣṭaṁ*, valat śobr̥ṁ* namasṭadḍi, niṣṭe maḍyamaṁ* hutamaṁ*, purvvakaṁ* mituva ḍaṇḍaṁ*,
ka, hana ta ya: vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, tinagiḥ pihutaṁnya, tan paveḥ vetan drəvenya, hasr̥ṁ saṁṅ apihutaṁ, maṅalap sadr̥venya, maṅalap histri, sunu, bhūmi, nūn pasu sakalviriṁ patik vənaṁ yata hinalap·, vetniṁ kaṁniṣṭa vinaṅūn mityeṁṅ ūjar,, maka:don hinira:-hira:, haṅiṅindəti, haṅlindihi, tan druḥ kaṁṅ adr̥ve vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, lumka:s kaṅśa:seṁ tan hambava cihna Utər· daL̥m, hikya ṅaran valat sahaṣa havalat śobra, hiṅar:vakən vinalik rantas vitya:, mvaṁ tinibakna ḍaṇḍa mahirantaṁn kaṁ sa:hasobradḍi, kunəṁ pinaraṅgvakna vutaṁ, lavan daṇḍanekaṁ sahaṣa, vnaṅ pasaṅana vrat niṣṭa maḍyotama, ye niṣṭa vit hutaṁ mvaḥ paṅamet· sinahaṣa:, niṣṭa: ḍaṇḍa,, 5000, yen madya paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 10000, hutama paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 20000, sapaṅamete haṅsula:kna riṁ kaṁṅ avutaṅ, vaṣana, ḍaṇḍa riṁ saṁ bhūpatya || 0 || kunaṁ Ikaṁ pratekaniṁ harta:, sapaṇna:, 20, limaṁ paṇa:, 2, ku, tkeṁ hartha, kunaṁ ikaṁ pirak pana sapuluḥ, ma:,L • Manuscript L inserts a substantial interpolation between two iterations of the lemma. The interpolation notably contains the full text of MDhŚ 8.139 and an unidentified Sanskrit stanza. Although having stanza 8.139, with paraphrase, in this general part of the text is potentially attractive, the fact that the stanza is quoted in full is suspect, and the precise locus where it is inserted interrupts the paraphrase of 8.137. On these grounds, we favor the hypothesis that the segment of text found only in this witness is extraneous to our text.

^654 . mā,] , om.LKM • In order for the arithmetic in this paragraph to work, we absolutely need this sentence to state a quantity of twelve and a half māṣas (i.e., 12 māṣa + 2 kupaṅ). Should we also supply ma before mā? Probably not, as ku in the last sentence is also not preceded by ma. For our author, ma, su seems to have been a fixed combination with ma no longer able freely to be combined with other units, as happens in the epigraphic corpus.

Translation

1

When the king is going to try a case, he should enter the court modestly accompanied by Brahmins and counselors who are experts in policy Now should his Majesty undertake to attend to litigation/affairs of this world, let him take as companions Brahmins who are knowledgeable and study Scripture, and likewise ministers with the wisdom to judge with discernment; with good conduct, he should enter the council.(1)
